Ethiopian Biometry Society (EBS)
The Ethiopian Region, founded in 1999, is an active Region of IBS. In addition to this, they are a member of the Sub-Sahara African Network, or SUSAN, which is a network of national biometric groups of the Sub-Saharan African countries that promote the advancement of life sciences through the development, application, and dissemination of effective mathematical and statistical methods.

This includes applications in agriculture, medical and health research, infectious diseases, environment and ecology, climate, and other applied sciences such as the areas of statistical genetics and bioinformatics.

title: Health Data Science: Data Visualizations and Wrangling with R
text:
Presented by: UKZN Data Science Group
Instructors:
- Prof. Temesgen Zewotir
- Prof. Henry Mwambi
- Prof. Retius Chifurira
- Prof. Faustin Habyarimana
- Dr. Zelalem Getahun
- Dr. Jesca Batidzirai
- Dr. Mohanad Mohammed


This intensive short course introduces essential skills in health data science, focusing on data wrangling and visualization using R. Participants will learn to clean, manipulate, and prepare health data for analysis, create compelling visualizations, and effectively communicate findings. Through hands-on exercises, students will gain practical experience with popular R packages such as dplyr and ggplot2, enabling them to transform complex datasets into clear insights. This course is ideal for beginners and healthcare professionals looking to enhance their data skills.




Understand the Role of Data Analysis: Grasp how data analysis informs healthcare decisions and policies.
Foundational R Programming Skills: Develop skills in R and become familiar with RStudio as a development environment.
Data Import and Export: Learn efficient methods for importing and exporting data in various formats.
Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr: Clean and manipulate health data by filtering, summarizing, and reshaping datasets.
Handling Missing Data: Identify missing values and apply strategies for imputation to maintain data integrity.
Creating Visualizations with ggplot2: Produce visualizations such as bar charts, scatter plots, and heatmaps to effectively communicate insights.
Interpreting and Communicating Results: Convey findings clearly to diverse audiences, emphasizing context and implications.
Case Studies in Health Data: Apply learned techniques to real-world health data sets in public health and clinical practice.
Ethics in Data Presentation: Understand the ethical implications, including privacy, bias, and responsible data use.
Continuous Learning: Foster a mindset of continuous improvement, encouraging collaboration and providing resources for further study.





Introduction to R for Health Data Science

Setting up R and RStudio
Basic R syntax and data structures (vectors, data frames, lists)

Data Import and Export

Importing data from various sources (CSV, Excel, databases)
Exporting cleaned data for analysis or reporting

Data Wrangling Techniques

Introduction to the tidyverse package
Using dplyr for data manipulation (filtering, selecting, arranging, summarizing)
Reshaping data with tidyr (pivoting, gathering, spreading)

Handling Missing Data

Identifying and understanding missing data
Strategies for imputation and data cleaning

Data Visualization Principles

Importance of visualization in health data science
Choosing the right type of visualization for different data types

Creating Visualizations with ggplot2

Introduction to ggplot2 syntax and structure
Creating basic plots: bar charts, histograms, scatter plots
Customizing visualizations (colors, labels, themes)

Advanced Visualization Techniques

Faceting and combining multiple plots
Visualizing time series data
Heatmaps and correlation plots

Interpreting and Communicating Results

Best practices for presenting visualizations
Writing effective captions and annotations
Ethical considerations in data presentation

Case Studies and Applications

Analyzing real-world health datasets (e.g., public health data, clinical trials)
Group projects on specific health issues

Resources for Further Learning


Recommended books, online courses, and communities
Exploring additional R packages for health data analysis

Workshop 3: Linear Mixed Model Analysis of Correlated Data


Presented by: Dr. Alison Kelly and Clayton Forknall The University of Queensland, Australia


Two- Day Training Course Outline


Course Description


Introduction to Linear Mixed Models: Understand the framework and its advantages for analyzing data from designed experiments.
Progressive Development: Start with simple linear models and gradually incorporate more complex fixed and random effects using Residual Maximum Likelihood (REML) estimation.
Complex Variance Structures: Learn how to extend models to fit complex variance structures that account for dependencies over time and space.
Practical Sessions: Engage in hands-on activities using the R statistical software package, allowing participants to analyze their own research data. Who Should Attend?

This workshop is ideal for researchers and practitioners in biological sciences who are looking to enhance their data analysis skills using linear mixed models. Whether you are new to the topic or seeking to deepen your understanding, this workshop will provide valuable insights and practical experience.

Don’t miss this opportunity to learn from experts and improve your data analysis capabilities!

text:
Workshop 1: Data Wrangling and Data Visualizations in Health Data Science with R


One- Day Training Course Outline


Course Description

This hands-on course provides a comprehensive introduction to data manipulation and visualization using R, specifically tailored for health data science. Participants will learn essential skills for cleaning, transforming, and visualizing healthcare datasets including patient records, clinical trials, and public health data. Through practical exercises, attendees will gain proficiency in using R’s Tidyverse ecosystem to derive insights from complex health data.

Course Prerequisites


Basic familiarity with R syntax and RStudio interface
Understanding of fundamental data types (vectors, data frames)


Course Outcomes


Clean and prepare messy health datasets for analysis
Perform advanced data transformations using dplyr and tidyr
Create publication-quality visualizations with ggplot2
Handle temporal health data and categorical variables effectively


Course Objectives


Master RStudio for health data analysis workflows
Develop strategies for handling missing values in medical datasets
Implement efficient data merging/joining techniques for multi-source health data
Create diagnostic visualizations for health metrics (blood pressure, age distributions, etc.)
Transform data between wide/long formats for different analytical needs
Generate time-series visualizations for patient monitoring and trend analysis

Welcome Note by the Chair of IBS Ethiopian Region


19th Biennial SUSAN Conference Date: September 3, 2025 Location: Addis Ababa, Ethiopia


Honorable guests, esteemed colleagues, and distinguished members of the International Biometrics Society,


It is an immense privilege to welcome you all to the 19th Biennial Conference of the Sub-Saharan Network (SUSAN) of the IBS. This gathering stands as a testament to our shared commitment to advancing biometrics and data science for the betterment of health and agriculture across the developing world.


As we convene here in Addis Ababa, we embark on a journey of knowledge exchange, collaboration, and innovation. The Ethiopian Biometric Society, alongside our partners at IBS, is deeply honored to host this distinguished event, bringing together some of the brightest minds in biostatistics, bioinformatics, artificial intelligence, and data science.


Our conference theme—“Biometrics and data science to enhance health and agriculture in the developing world”—reminds us of our duty to harness the power of data and analytics in solving real-world challenges. In an era marked by rapid technological evolution, the ability to analyze, predict, and optimize solutions has never been more critical. From addressing disease burden estimation to pioneering machine learning applications in agriculture, the insights shared over the next few days will shape the future of biometrics in vital sectors.


We extend our sincere gratitude to all researchers, academicians, practitioners, and students who have joined us for this occasion. The diversity of perspectives and expertise in this room serves as the driving force of innovation. As we move forward, let us remain committed to fostering ethical research, embracing collaboration, and ensuring that our work translates into tangible progress for communities in need.


Let this conference be a catalyst for change. Let it inspire groundbreaking discoveries, strengthen professional networks, and reinforce our shared vision for a data-driven future that uplifts societies across Africa and beyond.


Together, we shape tomorrow. Together, we build a legacy.


Welcome to IBS SUSAN 2025!

Call for Abstract: IBS SUSAN2025 Conference


The 19th Biennial Conference of the Sub-Saharan Network (SUSAN) of the International Biometrics Society (IBS)


Addis Ababa, Ethiopia 03-08 September 2025


Conference theme: Biometrics and data science to enhance health and agriculture in the developing world


Host: IBS Ethiopia Region/Ethiopian Biometric Society



About the Conference

The IBS Ethiopia Region/Ethiopian Biometric Society (EBS) is pleased to invite you to attend the Conference of the Sub-Saharan Network (SUSAN) of the International Biometrics Society (IBS). The Conference will cover a wide range of classical and Bayesian statistical theory and methods and data science, their applications in life sciences (health and agriculture).
The 19th Biennial IBS SUSAN 2025 Conference, an international event dedicated to advancements in biometrics and related fields. Organized in collaboration with the IBS, this conference aims to foster collaboration among researchers, academicians, practitioners, and students from around the globe. Participants will have the opportunity to share insights, discuss innovations, and explore future directions in these vital areas of study.
Join us in promoting knowledge exchange and networking on an international scale.

Sub themes:

We invite original research papers and reviews on themes including, but not limited to:

Biostatistics methodologies
Bioinformatics
Data science (machine learning, AI, big data analytics, predictive modelling)
Data analysis in biomedical and agriculture research
Ethical considerations in biometrics
Clinical trial study
Design of experiments
Bayesian methods
Categorical data analysis and discrete models
Computation intensive methods and software development
Longitudinal data analysis/mixed effects model
Missing and incomplete data
Time to event models and multistate models
Joint outcome models
Causal inference
Mixture models
Statistical approaches to omics data
Small area estimation
Spatio-temporal modelling
Meta analysis
Disease burden estimation
Others

Abstract submission: Please submit a maximum of a 300-word abstract by 31 March 2025. (Extended to: 30 April 2025)

Strengthening (Bio)Statistics and Data Science Education and Research Resources in Sub-Saharan Africa


Join us for an engaging session focused on capacity building and research enhancement in biostatistics and data science at universities across sub-Saharan Africa. Over the years, significant investments have been made in higher education, training, and research. Traditionally, these partnerships have followed a North-South donor-recipient model. However, recent developments highlight the importance of integrating robust South-South collaborations to create more effective educational partnerships.


This session will showcase several ongoing initiatives supported by various organizations, emphasizing mutual North-South-South partnerships that have emerged in recent years. The presentations will cover four key topics that have fostered capacity building in biostatistics and data science across the region.


Session Overview


The session will feature four 20-minute presentations:



Prof. Tobias Chirwa (University of the Witwatersrand, South Africa) will provide an overview of the SSACAB consortium, which aims to strengthen biostatistics education in sub-Saharan Africa.


Prof. Ann Mwangi (Moi University, Kenya) will discuss the long-term Moi-Brown collaboration focused on HIV biostatistics research training and capacity development activities.


Prof. Ziv Shkedy (Hasselt University, Belgium) will present an open-source E-learning platform, eR-Biostat, designed to support researchers, teachers, and students in statistics and data science.


Prof. Tarylee Reddy (SA-MRC, South Africa) will give an overview of the International Biometric Society’s (IBS) mentoring program and its activities in sub-Saharan Africa.



These initiatives exemplify diverse approaches to enhancing education and research in biostatistics and data science in sub-Saharan Africa. Each relies on strong collaborative networks and aims to produce sustainable deliverables that will remain accessible long after initial funding concludes.


Session Details



Chair: Prof. Samuel Manda (University of Pretoria, South Africa)


Discussant: Prof. Misrak Gezmu (NIH, USA)


Discussion: A 30-minute discussion will follow, focusing on developing sustainable education and research pathways in the region.



All presenters, the chair, and the discussant are actively involved in long-term projects that promote education and research in (bio)statistics and data science within sub-Saharan Africa.


Don’t miss this opportunity to learn about impactful initiatives and contribute to the discussion on strengthening our educational resources!

Workshop 2: Geospatial Mapping with R for Health Data R
One- Day Training Course Outline
Course Description
This course introduces geospatial data analysis and mapping using R, a powerful programming language for statistical computing and data visualization. Participants will learn to work with geospatial data, analyze spatial relationships, and create informative maps for visualizing geographic information in public health contexts. Through hands-on exercises, attendees will explore techniques for identifying spatial patterns, overlaying datasets, and communicating insights effectively.
